intro: Thelypodiopsis bakeri, commonly known as the Baker's sandspurry, is a low-growing, mat-forming plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae, which includes many flowering plants adapted to dry environments. The plant features small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in early spring, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. Its leaves are narrow and fleshy, typical of plants in arid climates, and it has a deep root system to access water. Thelypodiopsis bakeri is often found in sandy or rocky soils and is well adapted to withstand drought conditions.
